pullrequest.title: Spherical slicing and coordinates, making bounds for Cylindrical in Cartesian

content.raw: Wait -- they are "pixel" x, y planes, but not necessarily aligned with the actual axes, inasmuch as we have a fixed coordinate transformation.  For instance, if I place a cut at a fixed theta, the "x" and "y" axes won't be x, y as defined according to the unit circle.  (If I do phi slice, it probably will be okay.)
content.html: Wait -- they are "pixel" x, y planes, but not necessarily aligned with the actual axes, inasmuch as we have a fixed coordinate transformation. For instance, if I place a cut at a fixed theta, the "x" and "y" axes won't be x, y as defined according to the unit circle. (If I do phi slice, it probably will be okay.)

pullrequest.title: Spherical slicing and coordinates, making bounds for Cylindrical in Cartesian

content.raw:
True - what you call "x", "y", and "z" is also somewhat arbitrary.

Also we don't necessarily *need* to do a Cartesian pixelization: http://matplotlib.org/basemap/api/basemap_api.html

That said, this is clearly just a first step.  An awesome one at that, great job Matt!

How much more effort are you going to put into non-Cartesian coordinate systems before the 3.0 release?  I feel like this is 3.1 material.  I also worry about releasing incomplete functionality.
content.html:
True - what you call "x", "y", and "z" is also somewhat arbitrary.

Also we don't necessarily need to do a Cartesian pixelization: http://matplotlib.org/basemap/api/basemap_api.html

That said, this is clearly just a first step. An awesome one at that, great job Matt!

How much more effort are you going to put into non-Cartesian coordinate systems before the 3.0 release? I feel like this is 3.1 material. I also worry about releasing incomplete functionality.

pullrequest.title: Spherical slicing and coordinates, making bounds for Cylindrical in Cartesian

content.raw: So, Basemap does something different than what this does (it's also quite a heavy dependency) in that it puts it onto a projection of the sphere.  That would be "slicing along radius" in this notation, which isn't what the pixelizers primarily do.
content.html: So, Basemap does something different than what this does (it's also quite a heavy dependency) in that it puts it onto a projection of the sphere. That would be "slicing along radius" in this notation, which isn't what the pixelizers primarily do.

pullrequest.title: Spherical slicing and coordinates, making bounds for Cylindrical in Cartesian

content.raw:
"Slicing along radius" is a very important feature for most spherical applications, and having several available projections is, I think, essential for yt. 

However, there are loads of OTHER kinds of slices one might want to do: meridional slices that include the center, off-axis meridional slices, off-axis slices along the rotation axis, etc. I've attached a figure to illustrate what I mean. However, this is what I think the pixelizer is for, and in that case, we will need to figure out what to label the axes as.


![2014-04-07-103220.jpg](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BXbAb/images/1637408980-2014-04-07-103220.jpg)
content.html:
"Slicing along radius" is a very important feature for most spherical applications, and having several available projections is, I think, essential for yt.

However, there are loads of OTHER kinds of slices one might want to do: meridional slices that include the center, off-axis meridional slices, off-axis slices along the rotation axis, etc. I've attached a figure to illustrate what I mean. However, this is what I think the pixelizer is for, and in that case, we will need to figure out what to label the axes as.

pullrequest.title: Spherical slicing and coordinates, making bounds for Cylindrical in Cartesian

content.raw:
I *think* we have at least one projection already, I think aitoff?  It currently takes healpix but could be modified to take anything.

The other items you note are in fact important, and I agree completely.  I have not given a lot of thought yet to how to represent these -- as it stands, the only thing I've worked on is how to slice along the principal axes of the system (r, theta, phi) which does not cover the range of slices you're describing.  I'm wondering if we would need to write a different pixelizer for them; I suspect we would, but I may be wrong.  If we can translate the input coordinates (or supply translation information) such that it's identical to slicing along phi, we should be able to represent this with the existing pixelizer.
content.html:
I think we have at least one projection already, I think aitoff? It currently takes healpix but could be modified to take anything.

The other items you note are in fact important, and I agree completely. I have not given a lot of thought yet to how to represent these -- as it stands, the only thing I've worked on is how to slice along the principal axes of the system (r, theta, phi) which does not cover the range of slices you're describing. I'm wondering if we would need to write a different pixelizer for them; I suspect we would, but I may be wrong. If we can translate the input coordinates (or supply translation information) such that it's identical to slicing along phi, we should be able to represent this with the existing pixelizer.

pullrequest.title: Spherical slicing and coordinates, making bounds for Cylindrical in Cartesian

description:
This adds two things.

1) Spherical coordinate handling, including slicing and pixelizing and whatnot.
2) Specifying extents for cylindrical and polar coordinate pixelizing in extents, so you can pan/zoom in the coordinate system.

There is more that needs to be done -- for instance, making all the axis names correct, which means going through and finding all the places we use `axis_names` and `[xy]_dict` and fixing them![UniformGridData_Slice_z_density.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/RMxd9/images/332576197-UniformGridData_Slice_z_density.png).  But here's a script that generates some sample data:

http://paste.yt-project.org/show/4479/

and I've attached an image of this, where I've zoomed and then panned a bit to show it works in general.

UPDATE 1: Removing print statement.

UPDATE 2: Populating with NaNs.  New example image attached.![UniformGridData_Slice_z_density.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BXbAb/images/4169494679-UniformGridData_Slice_z_density.png)

UPDATE 3: Adding `geometry` option to GDF loading.

UPDATE 4: Adding an aitoff pixelization.  Example usage:

```
#!python
from yt.utilities.lib.misc_utilities import pixelize_aitoff
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 s = ds.slice(0, 0.5)
img = pixelize_aitoff(
                s["theta"], s["dtheta"]/2.0,
                s["phi"], s["dphi"]/2.0,
                (2048, 1024), s["density"], None, None).transpose()
plt.gcf().set_size_inches(12,6)
plt.imshow(img, origin='lower', interpolation='nearest', aspect=1.0)
plt.savefig("aitoff.png")
```

Note that it's not terribly fast.  Before this gets *used* everywhere, we need to get the API figured out, as I do not want to make the assumption that aitoff is what people want, nor that the slicing works such that "r" always does a surface projection.  (ping @jsoishi )

Forgot to attach an image:![aitoff.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BXbAb/images/2794961945-aitoff.png)

UPDATE: Fixing some orthogonal pixelization stuff.
